Brief Hospital Course: 50 y/o male w/ h/o EtOH abuse, UGI bleed, htn, pancreatitis, EtOH withdrawal sz presenting w/ EtOH intoxication and abd pain now with suspected withdrawal seizure requring high benzo doses.
1. EtOH withdrawl:
History of Etoh abuse and withdrawal seizure. He was intoxicated in the ED and had a witnessed seizure in that context. He received in total about 100mg of valium while in the ED. He was transferred to the [**Hospital Ward Name 332**] ICU for further monitoring. He was monitored by CIWA scale, and required minimal further benzodiazepines. He consistently had scores by CIWA scale of 0-2 and had no further signs/symptoms of withdrawal. He had no further seizures during his hospital course.
2. Acid-base: Primary hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis likely [**2-16**] vomiting, contraction. AG 22 c/w metabolic acidosis likely uremic. Lactate wnl 2.2. These acid/base disturbances, as well as hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia were all corrected with volume resuscitation and electrolyte repletion.
3. RLL opacity:
Persistent lung nodule in RLL seen on chest xray. Initially started on abx in ED, but these were d/c in ICU, as there was no clear evidence of infection. A chest CT was performed, which demonstrated a 3cm spiculated RLL nodule, concerning for malignancy, especially given his smoking history. He will need further f/u and diagnostic biopsy. The team discussed the lesion with Mr. [**Known lastname **], clearly stating that there was a high chance it was malignant and the best chance of cure would be excision. Mr. [**Known lastname **] indicated he understood and would follow up at a clinic appointment the team set up for him prior to his discharge.
4. ARF:
Consistent with pre-renal azotemia. Resolved with aggressive volume resuscitation. No further issues.
5. Follow up:
Complicated social situation with tenuous housing; lives on street as well as with children. Seen by SW while in house; offered etoh counseling/programs, but patient refused. He will f/u with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 333**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 334**] in [**Hospital 191**] clinic; on discharge, this appointment was set up. He will need to apply for MassHealth coverage as well. He agreed to f/u, and understands that he needs further f/u for this lung nodule.
Discharge Disposition: Home
Discharge Diagnosis: etoh intoxication, etoh withdrawal seizure
Discharge Condition: fair
Discharge Instructions: Call [**Hospital 191**] clinic to ensure that you have a follow up appointment with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 333**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 334**]. Please refrain from alcohol.
Followup Instructions: It is VERY important that you see a doctor regarding your lung nodule. It will need to be removed. Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 333**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 334**] here at [**Hospital1 18**] would be happy to follow up with you in his clinic. Call [**Telephone/Fax (1) 250**] for an appointment. If you would prefer to see Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 335**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] at [**Hospital1 336**] then call her office at [**Telephone/Fax (1) 337**].

EVENT.text: transferred to the [**Hospital Ward Name 332**] ICU
